author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Air Pollution (PM2.5)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Average daily density of fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air (μg/m³). Lower values = cleaner air.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV2. Poor air quality can negatively affect health outcomes; part of environmental baseline.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Drinking Water Violations

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Indicator of the presence of health-related drinking water violations in county water systems (yes/no, measured as % of population affected).

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV2. Reflects water quality infrastructure. Counties with violations score lower on environment.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Severe Housing Problems

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of households with at least 1 of 4 housing problems: overcrowding, high housing costs, lack of kitchen, or lack of plumbing. (Higher = more housing problems.)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV2. Captures built environment stresses; high housing problems can influence community health.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Driving Alone to Work

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of workers commuting alone by car. (High values along with long commutes indicate potential transit and infrastructure issues.)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV2. Included as an environmental factor (transportation mode). Contributes to index (higher solo driving can lower score slightly).

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Long Commute – Driving Alone

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of commuters who drive alone and have commutes >30 minutes. High values = many people with lengthy solo commutes.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV2. Reflects transportation infrastructure and spatial layout. Long solitary commutes can impact health (stress, less leisure time).

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Health Behaviors (IV3) – Composite index of community health behaviors

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Adult Smoking

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of adults (age ≥18) who are current smokers. (Lower is better for health.)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Key risk behavior – smoking rates strongly affect health outcomes. (Largest weight in IV3 ≈33%.)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Adult Obesity

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of adults (age ≥18) with Body Mass Index ≥ 30 (obese). Lower = better.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Captures diet and exercise-related health status. (Weight ~16.7% in IV3.)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Food Environment Index

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Index (0 to 10) of food access/security (accounts for grocery store proximity and food insecurity rates). Higher = better food environment.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Indicates healthy food availability in the county. (Lesser weight in IV3.)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Physical Inactivity

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of adults age 20+ reporting no leisure-time physical activity. Lower = better.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Sedentary lifestyle metric; contributes to chronic disease risk profile of community.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Access to Exercise Opportunities

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of population with adequate access to locations for physical activity (e.g. parks, gyms). Higher = better access.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Represents built environment support for exercise; included in behaviors index with small weight.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Excessive Drinking

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of adults reporting binge or heavy drinking. Lower = better.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Alcohol abuse prevalence – impacts health (weight ~8% in IV3).

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Alcohol-Impaired Driving Deaths

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of motor vehicle crash deaths that involve alcohol. Lower = safer driving behavior.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Reflects community safety and behavior; part of IV3 (weight ~8%).

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Sexually Transmitted Infections

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: STI rate: chlamydia incidence rate per 100,000 population. Lower = fewer STIs.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Proxy for risky sexual behavior in the community. (Weight ~8%.)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Teen Births

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Teen birth rate: number of births per 1,000 females ages 15–19. Lower = better (fewer teen pregnancies).

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV3. Reflects youth sexual health behavior and education; included in IV3 (weight ~8%).

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Social & Economic Factors (IV4) – Composite index of socioeconomic conditions

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – High School Completion

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of adults age ≥25 with a high school diploma or equivalent. Higher = more educated population.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV4. Education level indicator (contributes ~5% of IV4 score) – higher education correlates with better health outcomes.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Some College

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of adults ages 25–44 with some post-secondary education (college or training). Higher = better.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV4. Education access metric (~5% weight) – relates to workforce skill and health literacy.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Unemployment

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of population ages 16+ unemployed and seeking work (annual average). Lower unemployment = better economy.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV4. Economic stability indicator (~10% weight) – unemployment is linked to insurance status and health access.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Children in Poverty

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of children (<18) living in households below the federal poverty line. Lower = better.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV4. Key poverty indicator (~7.5% weight) – childhood poverty has long-term health implications.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Income Inequality

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Ratio of household income at the 80th percentile to that at the 20th percentile. Lower ratio = more equal income distribution.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV4. Inequality metric (~2.5% weight) – high inequality can adversely affect community health and social cohesion.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Children in Single-Parent Households

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Percentage of children living in single-parent households. Lower = more two-parent households (a proxy for social support).

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV4. Family stability indicator (small weight ~2.5%) – included as social factor influencing child outcomes.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Social Associations Rate

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Number of membership associations (civic, religious, leisure, etc.) per 10,000 population. Higher = more social community ties.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV4. Social capital indicator (~2.5% weight) – strong social networks can improve community health.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: – Injury Deaths (Violent Crime surrogate)

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Age-adjusted rate of deaths due to injury per 100,000 population. (Includes homicides, suicides, accidents.) Lower = safer community.

author: Aaron Johnson
snippet: Component of IV4. Proxy for community safety/violence (weighted ~5%). Used in place of or alongside crime rates; higher injury death rates can indicate risky environment.
